awd_titl_txt: Quantum Gases of Bosonic and Fermionic Lithium
awd_abstract_narration:
For electrons in solids it is well known that quantum many-body interactions cause material properties such as conductivity and magnetism.  For atoms in a gas, however, it is difficult to observe quantum many-body effects unless the atoms are very cold, because hot atoms behave more like ordinary ballistic particles.  This project will cool lithium atoms below one millionth of a degree Kelvin and manipulate gases of ultra-cold atoms in optical traps in  order to study how quantum mechanics influences large collections of atoms.  This will advance the science known as quantum many-body physics.  The advantage of using ultra-cold atoms is that their temperature, density, and traps can be readily controlled and adjusted.  This is important because it will help physicists understand phenomena such as superconductivity and exotic types of magnetism.  In particular, this project will study how magnetism and superconductivity co-exist.  This will improve the fundamental understanding of high-temperature superconductors, and may enable fabrication of new materials that superconduct at even higher temperatures.  Another part of this project will probe how quantum many-body phenomena affect the propagation of collective waves known as solitons.   This part of the project is important because it could lead to improved sensors.

Both parts of this project will use an isotope of lithium, in one case a boson, while in the other a fermion.  The goal of the proposed boson experiment is to explore the role of near-integrability in bright matter-wave solitons, either fundamental ones or higher-order soliton breathers. The plan is to create a breather using a protocol developed by theoretical collaborators, and to explore its interactions with a beam splitter formed from a blue-detuned light sheet. The goals are both fundamental and technological. One goal is to create a mesoscopic (N = 100-300) quantum object and observe its properties in a novel one-dimensional interferometer using the light sheet as a beam splitter. If the center-of-mass energy of the soliton is below the binding energy of a single atom, it will not fragment upon interacting with the beam splitter, but rather tunnel and reflect in its entirety, thus creating a Schrödinger cat state. In the second part of this project, this laboratory will implement new ideas for creating and directly detecting the exotic superconducting state known as FFLO (Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov state) with a spin-imbalanced Fermi gas. While FFLO is prevalent in 1D, both quantum and thermal fluctuations tend to destroy long-range order in lower dimensions. The recent determination from this laboratory of the phase diagram of the 1D-3D dimensional crossover in a gas of spin-polarized fermions points to a region in parameter space where FFLO is both prevalent and stable. The next goal for this team is to detect the periodic domain walls occupied by the unpaired fermions in time-of-flight expansion in 1D. This would constitute the first direct evidence for FFLO.

por.por_cntn:
One of the major goals of this grant was to observe and quantify an effect known as spin-charge separation, a phenomenon long-expected in a collection of many electrons confined to a one-dimensional “quantum” wire. As far as physicists can tell, electrons are point particles with three properties: mass, charge and spin. Spin is a quantum-mechanical analog of angular momentum, and in the case of the electron, can take one of two values, labeled as up and down. In two or three dimensions, all three of these properties move together.  In one-dimension (1D), however, something remarkable occurs: electrons confined to narrow wires in 1D behave as if they are not comprised of individual electrons, but rather two new types of waves: those that carry only charge, and those that carry only spin.

Spin-charge separation arises from the collective nature of excitations in 1D of electrons, or any other type of particle belonging to the class known as fermions. Any fermion that bumps into the one next to it will cause a ripple to propagate through the quantum wire, thus jostling all fermions in the chain. A collective ripple, or wave, may be excited by transferring momentum to them. If momentum is delivered to both spin states symmetrically, the excited waves consist of an excess of charge moving along the wire, but with no spin transport. On the other hand, if momentum is delivered to the two spin states asymetrically, only spin waves are excited, but no charge. Remarkably, spin waves slow down with increasing repulsion between fermions, while the charge part speeds up, and consequently, after a little time the spin and charge parts of the electrons spatially separate!

In our work, we realized a physical quantum simulation of 1D fermions. Instead of studying electrons in a wire, we used neutral atoms cooled to less than a millionth of a degree Kelvin above absolute zero, trapped in waveguides formed by tightly focused, intense laser beams. While the atoms are more than 10,000 times more massive than electrons and the details of the interactions between them are different, one can form a mathematical analogy between these two systems. We exploit this analogy to observe spin-charge separation, and to quantify the behavior of repulsive fermions in 1D.

The measurements performed with the quantum simulator are clean and precise, and thus also very quantitative.  Spin-charge separation has been studied in electrons in solid materials, but the inherent defects and impurities in solid-state lattices makes quantitative comparisons with theory challenging. In contrast, our measurements compare very well with the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid theory, providing strong confidence that our understanding of spin-charge separation is not only qualitatively correct, but for the first time, also quantitatively accurate.

The implications of our work extend to atom-scale wires in electronic devices, and possibly, to exotic quantum structures that may be useful as “topological qubits” for quantum computation.

While we observed spin-charge separation in a gas of atomic fermions, we also performed experiments with a class of atoms known as bosons, or Bose-Einstein particles.  At temperatures of around 1 micro-Kelvin above absolute zero, the bosons suddenly transform to a collective state of matter known as a Bose-Einstein condensate, after the individuals who proposed this exotic state.  We are able to tune the interactions of these bosons to be weakly attractive, and when they are also confined to 1D, they collapse into a self-bound macro-particle composed of tens of thousands of individual atoms called a soliton.  We are studying the excited states of solitons, known as breathers, created by suddenly increasing the strength of the attractive interactions.  Our goals for this line of research is to probe quantum effects in breathers to better understand how quantum mechanics is the correct theory for small systems of 1 to 10 atoms, but fails for systems composed of larger numbers of atoms.  The answer to this question is needed in order to scale quantum computers to larger, more useful, devices.
